string-array.name: basics_of_java_description
string-array.item: When learning about java its important to know about the syntax. An example of syntax would be the use of a semicolon ( ; ) at the end of a line to show the end of a statement. The following section will touch on the fundamental syntax used in java.\n\nUse this section as a point of reference if something In the coming examples are not clear.
Semi Colons ; – Are used to show where an instruction ends and a new instruction begins. This is similar to a full stop after a sentence and is required for the code to work.
Round Brackets ( ) - Are used to hold additional information for a function or to hold conditions for conditional statements. (This will be covered in Conditional Statements later.)
Square Brackets [ ] – Are used to create arrays which are used to store multiple values in a single variable.

Curly Brackets { } – Are used in Conditional Statements to help structure them. Imagine them as the front and back cover in a book holding together all the pages in between. (This will be covered in Conditional Statements later so just keep it in mind.)
Two slashes // - Are used to add comments to code on a single line. Anything after these slashes will be ignored by the program and just considered text.
Slash + asterisk /* Text */ - Is used to make multi-line comments. Anything in-between the /* and the */ will be ignored by java.
Printing out a message System.out.println(“Your Message Here”) - Is used to print out the text that is within the double quotations. This will be used in examples to output results.
Full Stop . – Is used when you want to access object attributes and methods.

The code examples that you will encounter in later sections will use a color schema that aims to help distinguish parts of the code.


Red Text - Signifies Classes.


Blue text - Signifies Conditional Statements.


Green Text - Signifies Text.

With these, the following examples should be more clear. This section aims to clarify the syntax used in the coming example. Don\'t worry if something doesn\'t make sense as these will be clarified later in the context of the sections they are used in.\n\n

string-array.item: Variables are used in programming to pair information such as names or numbers to a value that can be referenced later. The following example shows how this is formatted in java. \n\nType Name = value;
The Data Type determines what kind of data is being held. (this will be explored in more detail in the following section on Data Types)
The name is what will be used in the program to reference what is being stored (Such as x or name). Java is case sensitive so for example, “Number” and “number” are considered two different names.
This is used to assign the Variable to the Value. ‘The Variable Equals the value’.
The value stored in the variable depends on the type. Some types can only store specific values and some do it better than others. This will be explored more in the next section on data types.\n\n

string-array.name: data_types_description
string-array.item: This section will go over the fundamental Data types used in programming with java being the example language.
The int variable can hold whole numbers (1, 34, 190). This variable is the preferred option when handling simple numerical values.
The float data type is used when you want to store numbers with a decimal, such as 19.99 or 3.1415. additionally, the value should have an “ f ” at the end of the value.
The char data type is used when you want to store a single character such as ‘A’ or ‘T’. An example of this being used would be to store a pupils grade
The boolean data type is used when you want to store either a true or false value.
The String data type is used to store text surrounded by double quotations. Numbers can be used too as long as they are within the double-quotes.
A string in java is an object, which contains methods that can perform certain operations on strings. For example, the length of a string can be found with the length() method

In this example, the txt String uses the length() method to calculate this. The full stop after the txt String is used to access methods that can be used on Strings. The following is a list of what more can be done to strings


toUpperCase() - the toUpperCase() method changes all the characters in a string to upper case.


toLowerCase() - Similarly, the toLowerCase() method does the opposite and changes all the characters in a string to lower case.


Length() - The length() method returns the number of characters within a String.


*Note*

 Java counts positions from zero.

 0 is the first position in a String, 1 is the second, 2 is the third…

string-array.name: operators_description
string-array.item: Arithmetic operators are commonly used for mathematical operations.\n\n The following sections will look at the common operators.

Operator: +

 Description: Adds two values together.

 Example: 10 + 5 = 15

Operator: -

 Description: Subtracts one value from another.

 Example: 10 - 5 = 5

Operator: *

 Description: Multiplies one value by another 

 Example: 10 * 5 = 50

Operator: /

 Description: Divides one value by another 

 Example: 10 / 5 = 2

Operator: ++

 Description: Increases the value of a variable by 1 

 Example: 5++ = 6

Operator: --

 Description: Decreases the value of a variable by 1 

 Example: 5-- = 4
Comparison Operators are used when comparing two values or variables:

Operator: ==

 Description: Checks if two values are equal.

 Example: 5 == 3 : False.

Operator: !=

 Description: Checks if two values are not equal.

 Example: 5 != 3 : True.

Operator: >

 Description: Checks if a value is greater than another.

 Example: 5 > 3 : True

Operator: <

 Description: Checks if a value is less than another.

 Example: 5 < 3 : False

Operator: >=

 Description: Checks if a value is greater than or equal to another.

 Example: 5 >= 3 : True

Operator: <=

 Description: Checks if a value is less than or equal to another.

 Example: 5 <= 3 : False
Logical operators are used to determine the logic between variables or values. They are mainly used in conditional statements.

Operator: &&

 Description: Returns True if both Statements are true.

 Example: True && True : True

Operator: ||

 Description: Returns true if one of the two statements are True.

 Example: True || False : True

Operator: !

 Description: Reverses the Results, Returns true if false and vice versa.

 Example: !True : False

string-array.item:
Taking what you have learnt from the previous sections on operators we will now look into how and why they are used. 


Less Than: x < y


Less than or equal to: x <= y


Greater than: x > y


Greater than or equal to: x >= y


Equal to: x == y


Not Equal to: x!= y


You can use these to perform actions for different decisions.

 Java also has the following conditional statements.


Use if to specify a block of code to be executed, if a condition is true.


Use else to specify a block of code to be executed if the same condition is false.


Use else if to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false.
Use the if statement to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true.
In the example below, we test two values to find out if 20 is greater than 18. If the condition is true, run the code in the section within the Curly Brackets { }

The else statement specifies the code that will be run if the condition is false. This is paired with an if statement to have something happen if the condition is not met.

The example below will show how this will work following on from the previous example.

Loops can run a block of code as long as a specific condition is reached. This condition is usually a counter that reduces by 1 every time the block of code is run. This can be useful for running a block of code a certain amount of times before moving on.

While the variable i is less than 5, the code block will run. Within this block of code, there is a line of code to print out the variable i each time it runs. Additionally, if you remember back to the previous section on arithmetic operators, you will recall what the “++” operator does. As a refresher, it increments the variable i by 1 each time the code runs. So the program will print out each number until i reaches 4 then stop.\n\n

Statement 2 defines the condition for the loop to run ( i must be less than 5 ). If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if the statement is false, the loop will end.


Statement 3 increases a value ( i++ ) each the code block in the loop has been executed.

Break statements are used to jump out of a loop.

 In this example, a break is used to break out of a for Loop stopping it before it can print out all 10 of its numbers with an if statement.
